Award.AwardTitle: Geotechnology Experiences for Students and Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by its focus on geotechnology (also called GIS or geospatial information systems) careers. The programmatic goal of this project is to prepare teachers to engage middle and high schools students in high-needs and high-potential school districts with cutting-edge web GIS knowledge and skills in order to motivate students to pursue formal school-based and informal out-of-school educational experiences. Project research, guided by social-cognitive career development theory and other work, will investigate what programmatic experiences contribute to student motivation and cognitive gains and what factors contribute to teacher integration of GIS content into the school curriculum.

During three years of the project, the project will offer a summer teacher workshop and a student GIS summer camp each year, The camp will include field trips to GIS-related industry and government agencies, supported by mentors from these organizations. The workshop and camp will support teachers and students in learning GIS concepts and skills. Teachers will also learn approaches to integrate GIS- and career-related in STEM and social studies classes. Students who attended the summer camp will be supported in organizing a GIS after-school club. This project will research one of the guiding questions of the ITEST program: What coherent sets of experiences effectively and efficiently support student competency, motivation and persistence for productive participation in the STEM-related workforce of today and the future? The project will use mixed methods research design including a quasi-experimental study. Research findings from this project will help educators better understand and address the context and factors that influence integration of GIS in middle and high school curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Each year for three consecutive summers (2017-2019) ten teachers and fifteen middle and high school students worked collaboratively in a combination teacher professional development workshop and student summer STEM camp. The Geotechnology Experiences for Students and Teachers (GTEST) project at the University at Buffalo, SUNY was funded by the NSF ITEST program to engage teachers and students in geographic information systems (GIS) and analysis.  The camp curriculum and activities included several key components, for example including a unique emphasis on the use of aerial drones to develop aerial GIS maps.

The yearly cycle involved a recruiting component of teachers and students from Buffalo (NY) Public Schools and Niagara Falls Public Schools. Then, a three-week workshop typically beginning in mid-July would combine the talents of the teachers and students together. Teachers were responsible for learning the GIS material and devising lesson plans for implementation. Teachers were introduced to map making with accessible GIS software using cell phones. Students nominated from the teachers’ classrooms were able to learn about GIS and flight simulations for Drone mapping. But a major outcome of the combined workshop/camp showed us that the students could collaborate with the teachers because of their advanced facility to learn the software and envision the drone simulations as video games. Industry and government professionals presented to the workshop/camp on job opportunities in geotechnology. Students also participated in career counseling during the workshop/camp.  Finally, academic year support for teachers and students and their families focused on continuing support for implementation of the lesson plans with the students returning to classrooms to help teachers form after school clubs and provide leadership.

The creative and original concepts of this project lie in the following aspects: a cutting-edge IT field, a technology-rich learning environment, integrating IT into current science and social studies curriculum, a rigorous research design, and a strong industry involvement. The summer workshop/camp directly addressed the workforce shortages of an important emerging IT field (as identified by the US Department of Labor). The Web GIS technology serves as both a learning instrument and the learning subject. The unity between these two aspects of learning is expected to make the learning process fun and effective. The extensive involvement of a team of mentors from the university and industrial was another unique feature of the project. It is anticipated that the mentor team can effectively nurture and guide teachers and students interest toward their preparedness for entering into the IT workforce.

An integral part of this project is research on educating middle school and high school students and teachers to use cutting-edge IT knowledge and skills. The effectiveness of using GIS as both content and a teaching tool, and the extensive involvement of mentors in classrooms and after-school clubs will be studied. Research findings from this project will help us better address and understand the context and factors that influence integration of GIS in middle and high school curriculums.

The broader impact of the summer camp is designed to stimulate the interest of middle and high school students in pursuing careers in geotechnology in order to address the shortages in the workforce of this emerging IT field. Experiences gained in the process can be extended to other parts of the country in order to address national needs. The project engaged students in underserved school districts, thus broadening the participation of underrepresented populations in the IT workforce. The prepared workforce in various IT fields in turn empowers citizen sciences and cultivates an information-based and spatially aware society. The research questions contributed to advancement of new knowledge and understanding on middle and high school students’ spatial thinking abilities.
